title: Snapshot creation slows down archive node
body:
#### System information

Geth version: Geth/v1.10.3-stable-991384a7/linux-amd64/go1.16.3
OS & Version: Linux, GKE
Resources: 8TB SSD (GCP), 3 CPU, 12GB RAM

#### Expected behaviour
* archive node  stays in sync and not lagging behind
* snapshot is creating for a reasonable amount of time

#### Actual behaviour
* archive node is lagging behind
  ```
  INFO [05-21|08:46:17.892] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=218 mgas=14.953 elapsed=2m50.183s    mgasps=0.088 number=12,385,311 hash=f0ab52..69a230 age=2w3h20m   dirty=0.00B
  ```
* snapshot is not going to be finished  for reasonable amount of time
```
INFO [05-21|08:46:17.834] Resuming state snapshot generation       root=1787da..84738e at=008f65..483efb accounts=287,026 slots=1,055,799 storage=89.36MiB elapsed=7h27m8.326s  eta=3398h25m45.54s
```

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
* update synced geth archive node to geth version with snapshot( enabled by default)
* node begins to lag
* node syncs up with 4x-5x speed after `--snapshot=false`




I suppose the issue is in SSD latency, as it is a cloud SSD, not a local NVME, but anyway.

After the upgrade, Geth node needs to generate the snapshot which essentially traverses the entire state trie and it's really expensive, especially for the disk IO. And what's more because you are running the archive node which has a super large database, so the IO cost is even higher(slow disk read).

We had a bunch of optimizations for the snapshot generation, but it requires a fresh new snap sync. So it's not suitable for your use case.

I would suggest to disable the snapshot for your use case. Any opinions @holiman @karalabe ?

Perhaps another solution is: Geth can support to import/export the snapshot data. So that you can run a snap sync somewhere else(the sync should be synced in a few hours) and export the snap data into your archive node. 

Then your archive node will pick it up for repair, and the entire repair work can be finished in a few hours.

This is an annoying thing indeed. I'd still say archive node should also have snapshots, since they are a DoS defense mechanism, but I do see that it take a large toll to generate it and there's no clear way to make it faster (vs. snap syncing a full node).

Export and import isn't a particularly bad idea, but relying on "extra" out-of-protocol steps is a bit unfriendly. Even for power users it's probably very hard to remember and do correctly. Disabling the snapshots works for now, but we wanted to drop that flag, so it's not an obvious solution either. Will need to ponder about this a bit more.

Geth node works fine with snapshots disabled. Let me know if you need to perform some tests, trying a dev branch build over this node etc.

>So that you can run a snap sync somewhere else(the sync should be synced in a few hours)

Is it archive node snapshot?

We're seeing the same.
Since upgrading our nodes from `1.10.1` to `1.10.3` about 3:45 h ago they have accrued a sync backlog of ~15m.

DB size is about 1.4 TB.

Would it be possible to reduce IO priority of the snapshot generation task so that block import won't starve?

It's inefficient to do block processing at the same time as generation. Normally, after a sync, it's only a handful of blocks which are imported _during_ generation, which gives the generator only a few hundred millisecond to run before being interrrupted again. And after that, the generator can work for 14 seconds before it's interrupted next time. If you're falling further behind, that means that you're stuck in this poor-performance-case. 

I think one problem with only letting the generator execute short bursts of time is that each time it starts anew, it needs to construct new iterators. So, aside from more drastic fixes such as what Gary suggested, it might be worth a shot to see if the speed improves by shutting off the peers. If you have a live node which you don't want to restart, you could e.g. set maxPeers to zero, or netrestrict to localhost. Once it has chugged through the backlog, it will do _only_ generation, and once that's done, you can hook it up to peers again. 

YMMV, but it would be interesting to know what effect that has on your node.

For now I've disabled snapshot generation since we urgently need the nodes at the moment. 
But once we've finished our release cycle I'll test your idea.

25800

در تاریخ دوشنبه ۷ ژوئن ۲۰۲۱،‏ ۲۱:۳۲ Ulrich Petri ***@***.***>

> at the moment.
> But once we've finished our release cycle I'll test your idea.
>

@holiman 
> you could e.g. set maxPeers to zero

tried and that's what I see
```
INFO [06-07|20:31:30.275] Generating state snapshot                root=f1f7a8..affd32 in=008f65..483efb at=3298ff..309d77 accounts=298,869 slots=2,275,570 storage=197.29MiB elapsed=1h4m19.077s eta=488h50m29.963s
```
No other activities on the node at all. Here is [full log](https://gist.github.com/4d7b75901d918d45d762517f22654dc1) just in case. 

Estimated time grows up too.
```
INFO [06-07|20:35:38.409] Generating state snapshot                root=f1f7a8..affd32 in=008f65..483efb at=347299..d9f173 accounts=298,869 slots=2,319,415 storage=201.16MiB elapsed=1h8m27.211s eta=520h16m24.88s
...
INFO [06-07|21:27:24.052] Generating state snapshot                root=f1f7a8..affd32 in=008f65..483efb at=4b3773..2f4de6 accounts=298,869 slots=2,864,006 storage=249.17MiB elapsed=2h0m12.854s  eta=913h40m30.835s
```

An estimate grew up to 5+ months and coming ``` INFO [06-08|03:31:51.635] Generating state snapshot root=f1f7a8..affd32 in=008f65..483efb at=ea99d0..d7a174 accounts=298,869 slots=6,668,482 storage=584.67MiB elapsed=8h4m40.437s eta=3683h42m40.911s ``` With this estimate it's not going to finish in a reasonable amount of time, thus I have to revert to disabled snapshots. Here is the disk utilization

Duplicate of https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/22839, but I think we should continue the discussion here and close the other issue as there is more context here.

In our experience, 1.10.1 has no problem generating snapshot with full archive node, neither does 1.10.3 up until a point where the last snapshot generation stopped, at that time it seems that it hits some sort of infinite loop

Still same with 1.10.5, snapshot generating goes fine until it hits some point as stated above. 

After that geth monitoring shows huge disk reading and it is not hitting cache anymore. However from operating system we don't see that disk activity. Block processing grows from ~1s to 30s.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74717373/126118349-8faf977b-0edc-4626-93ba-abd5800565b5.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74717373/126118404-8cb33776-72fd-4087-ba5b-b797baba32b4.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74717373/126118733-bfdcb875-ae46-483c-ab61-30849533866c.png)

relevant log:
```

```

@farmer69420 

Are you node accepting some heavy requests? 

`Jul 19 06:01:05 ethnode geth[1128]: WARN [07-19|06:01:05.197] Served eth_call                          conn=REDACTED:50976 reqid=483           t=1m13.325197556s err="execution aborted (timeout = 5s)"`

It shows that Geth uses more than 1 minute to serve this `eth_call` request. It might be relevant with the performance degradation. Or maybe the machine is overhead that can't serve the single request.
The timeouts happen when a node becomes unsynchronized for requests like `eth.getBalance`. But the node becomes unsynchronized before serving requests, due to this bugged snapshot generation.
